8.79.text:
Show of hands, who makes
a conscious effort to be yourself?

17.53.text:
I think trying to be yourself
makes you just like everyone else

24.01.text:
My feeling is that you should
try to be unique -

28.52.text: By trying to be like everybody else.

31.72.text: And it'll make you normal, which is good.

38.09.text:
I do believe that the most dangerous
liability in our world today

45.79.text:
Think about it: if you are being yourself,
someone might actually find out

51.75.text:
who you really are,
they might actually see you.

56.09.text:
You might actually find out who you are.
People might make fun of you.

63.46.text: They might actually accept you too.

75.35.text:
I really advocate
a posture in life of being normal

79.79.text:
to help protect you
from these great threats.

87.46.text:
At least this is
what our imaginations say,

93.19.text: I mean, it sounds a little ridiculous.

96.10.text:
But I think what's actually
more ridiculous than how it sounds

99.90.text:
is the fact that we all
act this out to some degree.

104.70.text:
It's also a fact that I just called
my opinion a fact.

110.60.text: So it's like scientific, which is great.

115.23.text:
Another of my opinions is
the most pervasive disease

119.28.text: in our world today is being normal.

123.31.text:
It infects a lot of people.
It infects 90% of people.

129.67.text:
The other 10% are also affected
but they don't know it,

156.02.text:
Woman in the audience: Thank you so much.
JP: You're welcome.

160.91.text:
To me, they're really quite ugly,
they just look like weeds.

164.14.text: But I hope they cheer you up.

173.95.text:
How would you know if you're a doctor?
I assume someone tells you.

177.06.text:
But anyway, it's my opinion
I'm not a doctor,

184.45.text:
it's caused by a fear-based mindset
of self-rejection.

192.55.text:
It's like, when we're being normal
and that becomes the religion we worship,

199.18.text: we treat ourselves like the enemy.

202.41.text:
We reject ourselves
because that ensures us

206.00.text: nobody else is going to reject us.

207.98.text:
If I reject me first,
then you don't get any of me,

211.44.text: because I don't bring me to the table,

213.65.text:
so you can never reject me
as long as I'm rejecting myself.

221.82.text:
It's like, I'll kill myself,
so that I don't die.

226.65.text: Nobody else can kill me if I die first.

231.58.text:
Honestly, I think we laugh
because it's true.

237.74.text:
I can feel you're
telepathically asking me,

239.89.text: "JP, is there a cure for normal?"

244.99.text:
I believe so. To me, the cure
for normal is your weirdness.

250.65.text:
Not someone else's weirdness,
but your weirdness is the cure.

256.53.text:
Show of hands, who in here is naked
under your clothes right now?

260.97.text:
Cool. So you're all a bunch
of naked weirdos.

265.84.text: The cure is inside of you.

270.89.text:
You don't need to go
figure out how to be weird.

274.05.text: I think the design team that makes us,

275.95.text:
they are way too intelligent
to actually make us just normal.

280.42.text:
They want life a little more
interesting than that.

284.00.text:
By the way, that statement
has not been evaluated

286.32.text: by the Food and Drug Administration.

297.78.text:
your weirdness is a big part
of what makes you - you.

304.47.text:
Does anybody in here know
what the purpose of life is?

307.87.text: Yeah. Oh, God. I guess that's the purpose.

314.17.text: We're done, we just figured it out.

318.06.text:
Aside from the one narcissist
who actually thinks

325.34.text: I don't know what the purpose of life is.

328.11.text:
But if I was pretending

331.50.text:
I think it would have a lot to do

336.93.text:
You actually giving yourself permission
to be the miracle that you are,

341.12.text: and expressing that, not hiding that.

344.23.text:
It's kind of interesting
how we're given this life,

346.63.text:
which I judge to be
something incredibly precious,

351.42.text:
and then I'm amazed at how much of my time
I spend hiding this precious life

369.41.text:
What if the purpose of your life
was actually to be yourself?

375.08.text:
Can you slice through the psychological
scar tissue of your programming

382.19.text:
so that the miracle of you

395.43.text:
Which is kind of normal for stages,

400.33.text:
To me, weirdness is something

406.89.text: So here's my definition of weirdness.

410.36.text:
It's the traits, the tendencies,
the behaviors, the perspectives

419.26.text: Again, it's nothing we need to acquire.

421.94.text:
I think it's something
we're incarnated with.

426.89.text:
The question is: can you take off what you
cover up your raw, naked weirdness with?

433.97.text: Some of us would be sitting here saying,

435.94.text:

to be weird, but I'm just normal.

441.21.text:
I wear a suit and I actually pay

446.07.text:

451.23.text:
What I hear you say is
you're actually in denial.

460.24.text:
Whoever invented this style of microphone

464.98.text: It's like a water bottle company saying,

466.89.text:
"This water bottle is meant
to be held by your ear."

473.86.text: Which brings me to my next point.

479.06.text:
In fact, you're probably weirder
than you can think.

484.51.text:
Question for you:
who inspires you the most?

489.37.text:
Think of the person
who inspires you the most.

494.49.text: And yell out a name for me.

498.01.text: What I'm hearing you all say is JP Sears.

507.26.text:
because I don't want

516.05.text: JP: Myself. Okay. I like that.

518.88.text:

523.48.text:
like Elon Musk, Richard Branson,

529.92.text:
the question is:
what about them inspires you?

533.69.text:
My delusional opinion is what inspires you

539.35.text:

other people by excelling at normalcy.

552.63.text:
I think really what inspires us
about inspirational people

556.53.text:
more than their weirdness
is the fact that their weirdness

563.80.text:
We actually get exposed
to the surface area of who they are.

571.51.text:
Because they're willing to risk
being their unapologetically weird selves.

576.26.text:
And somehow, we get inspired
when we see someone else being themselves.

580.47.text:
We trick ourselves;
we think we're inspired

582.90.text:
because of what they do or what they have,
but I think that's just a delusion.

586.57.text:
I think we're really inspired by them
being willing to risk being themselves.

593.07.text:
I might me the only one -
but I might not be too.

597.45.text:
I think we're all very thirsty
to experience ourselves.

603.04.text:
When we see someone else
drinking themselves -

605.57.text:
and again, not what they do,
not what they have, but who they are,

610.80.text:
they're ripping their normal clothes off
and we see them being themselves -

615.44.text: we say, "I want some of that."

622.17.text:
What if you found out your weirdness
is a gluten-free bread crumb trail

626.29.text: that always leads you to you -

634.00.text: I don't like to worship weirdness;

636.54.text:
I love to worship
where weirdness leads us,

640.93.text:
which was really hard
for me to say just then.

645.13.text:
It's a really abnormal sentence

649.95.text:
So why I am a huge fan of weirdness is
it's my dogmatic belief

654.24.text: it always leads us to who we really are.

657.53.text:
Not who we think we are,
not even who we want to be,

660.93.text:
but something far more significant -
it leads us to who we actually are,

666.34.text:
if we're willing to follow
the scent trail of our weirdness.

671.29.text:
On paper, being weird and not apologizing

678.66.text:
So why do we constipate ourselves
from expressing

682.98.text:
our unapologetically weird selves?
Why do we do it?

688.93.text:
Well, because there's nothing
but awkward silence

691.25.text:

695.69.text:

698.45.text:
and therefore the expression

which just means you had

733.73.text:

740.72.text:

746.48.text:

752.94.text:
When I feel approved of,

757.58.text:

760.67.text: we typically have to work to find them.

764.23.text:

800.37.text:
especially if you mirror to them

815.72.text:

my weirdness, yes,

912.02.text:

954.18.text:
when I am significantly handsome,

1052.36.text:
that I'm telepathically sensing

Brené Brown, she's one

I don't think anybody has ever been hurt

1276.80.text:
the direction we need

1295.67.text:

Another consideration
I'd ask you to consider,

1338.76.text:

can you challenge yourself

1365.92.text:
what we were made fun of for the most,
what we were most embarrassed about,

1370.23.text: what we were shamed for the most -

1377.68.text: As a child, we look at our weirdness,

1380.29.text:
whether it's someone
who's making fun of us

1382.33.text:
because we're the only one

but we're meant to pretend

we think we're the only one

As a child, we tend to experience

1418.44.text:
any time we have
a sense of "I'm the only one."

1423.86.text:
The wounded child inside says,

1427.92.text:
But when we can bring that child

1432.73.text:
not in a bad way, but in a support
the inner child kind of way -

1437.80.text: we can be a more whole person today

1439.68.text:
and say, "Yeah, I'm the only one,

1444.15.text:
Would you be willing

find the blessing of it,

that I'd ask you to leave here with

of "part of the purpose of my life

it'll help posture you better

1476.63.text:
Allegedly, there's a story where Moses

simply by looking at you,

1503.95.text:
there is hilarious,

1537.42.text:
Would you be willing to consider that

1563.66.text:

1569.23.text:

1572.56.text:

When you look at
